stem: A 6-year-old child with a history of asthma is brought to the emergency department. The child is wheezing, has a respiratory rate of 36, and an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. The nurse is preparing to administer medications. Determine the actions the nurse should take and the actions the nurse should avoid.

itemContext.sbar: S: Alex Johnson, a 6-year-old male, presented to the ED at 14:30 with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. He has a history of asthma. B: The mother reports symptoms started this morning and have progressively worsened. The child used his albuterol inhaler at home with minimal relief. A: Respiratory rate is 36, oxygen saturation is 88% on room air, and audible wheezing is present. The patient is alert and responsive but anxious. He is using accessory muscles to breathe. R: Preparing to administer medications as ordered, including oxygen and nebulized albuterol. Continuous monitoring of respiratory status is essential. Consider chest X-ray to rule out other causes.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: Heart Rate: 130 bpm Respiratory Rate: 36 breaths/min Oxygen Saturation: 88% on room air Temperature: 37.2°C (99.0°F) Blood Pressure: 110/70 mmHg

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: ABG: pH: 7.30 PaCO2: 50 mmHg PaO2: 60 mmHg HCO3: 24 mEq/L CBC: WBC: 12,000/mm3

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Anxious, alert, and responsive Respiratory: Audible wheezing, increased work of breathing, use of accessory muscles Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, regular rhythm Skin: No cyanosis observed

tabs.content: Chest X-Ray: No acute infiltrates or consolidation noted.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Albuterol: 2.5 mg nebulized every 20 minutes as needed Ipratropium: 0.5 mg nebulized every 20 minutes as needed Oxygen: 2L via nasal cannula

rationale.correct: Administering a bronchodilator such as albuterol helps to open the airways and improve breathing by relaxing the bronchial smooth muscles, leading to bronchodilation. Administering oxygen helps to increase the oxygen saturation by increasing the partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli, facilitating oxygen diffusion into the bloodstream. Monitoring respiratory status helps to assess the effectiveness of the interventions and detect any deterioration in the child's condition. Elevating the head of the bed promotes optimal lung expansion by reducing pressure on the diaphragm and improving ventilation.
rationale.incorrect: Administering a sedative can depress the respiratory drive and worsen the child's condition by reducing the patient's ability to maintain adequate ventilation. Placing the child in a supine position can restrict lung expansion by increasing pressure on the diaphragm and reducing lung volume. Withholding fluids can lead to dehydration and thickened secretions, making it harder to clear the airways. Waiting to administer medications can delay treatment and worsen the child's condition, potentially leading to respiratory failure.
clinicalPearls: Asthma exacerbations in children require prompt treatment with bronchodilators and oxygen to prevent respiratory failure.
Regular assessment of respiratory status, including oxygen saturation and respiratory rate, is crucial to monitor the effectiveness of interventions and detect any deterioration.
Early intervention with appropriate medications and supportive care can significantly improve outcomes in children with asthma exacerbations.
rationale.questionTrap: The question traps are related to actions that would be detrimental to a child experiencing an asthma exacerbation, such as administering sedatives (which can depress respiratory drive) or withholding fluids (which can lead to dehydration and thickened secretions).
